resources.string: Baby First Aid for Parents
"What this is:"

"Basically a help to refresh your memory about some crucial things that can save your baby's life.
 This is not a fully fledged or definitive first aid course. For that you need to consult professional and personal advice, practice the actions with dummies and so on.
 A smart phone app or an online course cannot provide you with the practical knowledge needed to save lives.
 But they can help. And that is exactly what this Baby First Aid for Parents QuizApp is trying to do by asking you some (potentially) vital questions."
Start Quiz
How this quiz works:

"For each of a total of nine questions you'll see four possible answers. At least one of them is correct, but more often than not there are more than just one correct answers. And there are questions where all four answers are correct.\n You pick all the answers which you think of as correct. Then you click the button below the answers and the app will tell you immediately, if your choice of answers is correct or not. If not you will be redirected to the question and your answer(s) to reconsider.\n There are no points involved. You cannot rate the survival of your baby. It is a Yes-or-No-matter — ok, exaggerating here … but it is, isn't it?"

How to place your baby in the recovery position?
"Cradle her/him in your arms."
"Hold the baby upside down."
"Hold the baby so the head is tilted slightly downwards."
"Hug the baby and cuddle."

Question Two
How to open the baby’s airway?
Place one hand on the baby’s forehead and gently tilt the head back.
Place one hand on the baby’s head and gently tilt it forward.
Place your other hand on the baby’s chest and push gently.
Place one fingertip of your other hand on the point of the baby’s chin.
Question 3
Question Three
What to do if your baby is choking?
Slap it out! Give up to five back blows between their shoulder blades with the heel of your hand.
Pick it out! Carefully pick out any obvious objects with your fingertips.
Squeeze it out! Using two fingers, give up to five downward chest thrusts.
Hurl it out! Grab your baby by the legs and turn until your throws up the object.

Question Four
What to do if your baby if your baby has fever or high temperature above 37°C/98.6°F?
Check temperature ideally using an electronic thermometer placed under the armpit or a digital ear thermometer.
Bathe your baby in cold water to bring down the temperature.
Make them comfortable: don’t overdress them or remove too much clothing.
Give them regular drinks: if they are breastfed, feed them regularly. If your baby is no longer breastfeeding, you can offer them water to drink.
Question 5
Question Five
What are possible symptoms for seizures in babies?
Vigorous shaking with clenched fists and an arched back.
Twitching of their face and squinting, fixed or upturned eyes.
Holding their breath, with a red, puffy face and neck, and drooling at the mouth.
Possible vomiting and loss of control of their bowel or bladder.
Question 6
Question Six
What to do in case your baby has a seizure?
Put your baby into the recovery position.
Fix your baby with a blanket or pillow to protect her/him from hurting herself/himself.
Put pillows around your baby: protect your baby from hurting herself/himself, but don’t restrain her/him or try to move them.
When the seizure has stopped, remove any excess clothing or bedding, or open a window to cool your baby down to a sensible temperature.
Question 7
Question Seven
What are possible symptoms of hypothermia?
Body temperature below 35°C/95°F.
Shivering, cold, pale, and dry skin.
Slow and shallow breathing.
Slow and weakening pulse.
Question 8
Question Eight
What to do in case your baby shows symptoms of hypothermia?
Let your baby take a bath in water of medium temperature to slowly raise the body temperature.
Warm her/him up! Get your baby inside, give her/him something warm to drink, cover her/him with layers of blankets.
Find something for them to lie on to protect them from the cold ground.
If their clothes are wet, change them into dry clothes, if possible. Put them in a sleeping bag and cover them with blankets, if available.
Question 9
Question Nine
How to perform CPR (cardiopulmonary resuscitation) on your baby?

Chest compression: Place two fingertips of your lower hand on the center of the baby’s chest. Press down vertically on the breastbone, and press the chest down by at least one-third of its depth. Release the pressure and allow the chest to come back up. Do this at a rate of about twice a second. Performing this 30 times in a row is one sequence of chest compression and follows two sequences of rescue breath.

Rescue Breath: Clear and open your baby’s airway, take a breath in, place your lips around the baby’s mouth. Blow into the mouth until the chest rises. Remove your mouth and allow the chest to fall. Performing this three times in a row is one sequence of rescue breath. Three sequences of rescue breath follow up on chest compression.

Chest compression: Place your fingertips of your lower hand on the center of the baby’s chest. Press down vertically on the breastbone, and press the chest down by at least one-fourth of its depth. Release the pressure and allow the chest to come back up. Do this at a rate of about once a second. Performing this 40 times in a row is one sequence of chest compression and is followed by three sequences of rescue breath.

Rescue Breath: Clear and open your baby’s airway, take a breath in, place your lips around the baby’s mouth and nose to form an airtight seal. Blow steadily into the mouth until the chest rises. Remove your mouth and allow the chest to fall. Performing this five times in a row is one sequence of rescue breath. Two sequences of rescue breath is followed by chest compression.
